column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER VII .
#Text=LAND RATS AND WATER RATS
#Text=I will say no more about our passage except that we were three days at sea .
#Text=Then , when I woke one morning , I found that we were fast moored to a gay little wharf , paved with clean white cobbles , on the north side of the canal .
#Text=Strange , outlandish figures , in immense blue baggy trousers , clattered past in wooden shoes .
#Text=A few Dutch galliots lay moored ahead of us , with long scarlet pennons on their mastheads .
#Text=On the other side of the canal was a huge East Indiaman , with her lower yards cockbilled , loading all three hatches at once .
#Text=It was a beautiful morning .
#Text=The sun was so bright that all the scene had thrice its natural beauty .

#Text=The clean neat trimness of the town , the water slapping past in the canal , the ships with their flags , the Sunday trim of the schooner , all filled me with delight , lit up , as they were , by the April sun .
#Text=I looked about me at my ease , for the deck was deserted .
#Text=Even the never-sleeping mate was resting , now that we were in port .
#Text=While I looked , a man sidled along the wharf from a warehouse towards me .
#Text=He looked at the schooner in a way which convinced me that he was not a sailor .
#Text=Then , sheltering behind a bollard , he lighted his pipe .
#Text=He was a short , active , wiry man , with a sharp , thin face , disfigured by a green patch over his right eye .
#Text=He looked to me to have a horsey look , as though were a groom or coachman .

#Text=After lighting his pipe , he advanced to a point abreast of the schooner 's gang-way , from which he could look down upon her , as she lay with her deck a foot or two below the level of the wharf .
#Text=“ Chips aboard ? ” he asked , meaning , “ Is the carpenter on board ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , ” I said .
#Text=“ Will you come aboard ? ”
#Text=He did not answer , but looked about the ship , as though making notes of everything .
#Text=Presently he turned to me .
#Text=“ You 're new , ” he said .
#Text=“ Are you Mr. Jermyn 's boy ? ”
#Text=I told him that I was .
#Text=“ How is Mr. Jermyn keeping ? ” he asked .
#Text=“ Is that cough of his better ? ”
#Text=This made me feel that probably the man knew Mr. Jermyn .
#Text=“ Yes , ” I said .
#Text=“ He 's got no cough , now . ”
#Text=“ He 'd a bad one last time he was here , ” the man answered .
#Text=For a while he kept silent .
#Text=He seemed to me to be puzzling out the relative heights of our masts .
#Text=Suddenly he turned to me , with a very natural air .
#Text=“ How 's Mr. Scott 's business going ? ” he asked .
#Text=“ You know , eh ?
#Text=You know what I mean ? ”
#Text=I was taken off my guard .
#Text=I 'm afraid I hesitated , though I knew that the man 's sharp eyes noted every little change on my face .
#Text=Then , in the most natural way , the man reassured me .
#Text=“ You know , ” he said .
#Text=“ What demand for oranges in London ? ”
#Text=I was thankful that he had not meant the other business .
#Text=I said with a good deal too much of eagerness that there was , I believed , a big demand for oranges .
#Text=“ Yes , ” he said , “ I suppose so many young boys makes a brisk demand . ”
#Text=I was uneasy at the man 's manner .
#Text=He seemed to be pumping me , but he had such a natural easy way , under the pale mask of his face , that I could not be sure if he were in the secret or not .
#Text=I was on my guard now , ready for any question , as I thought , but eager for an excuse to get away from this man before I betrayed any trust .
#Text=“ Nice ship , ” he said easily .
#Text=“ Did you join her in Spain ? ”
#Text=“ No , ” I answered .
#Text=“ In London . ”
#Text=“ In London ? ” he said .
#Text=“ I thought you 'd something of a Spanish look . ”
#Text=“ No , ” I said .
#Text=“ I 'm English .
#Text=Did you want the carpenter , sir ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , ” he answered .
#Text=“ I do .
#Text=But no hurry .
#Text=No hurry , lad . ”
#Text=Here he pulled out a watch , which he wound up , staring vacantly about the decks as he did so .
#Text=“ Tell me , boy , ” he said gently .
#Text=“ Is Lane come over with you ? ”
#Text=To tell the truth , it flashed across my mind , when he pulled out his watch , that he was making me unready for a difficult question .
#Text=I was not a very bright boy ; but I had this sudden prompting or instinct , which set me on my guard .
#Text=No one is more difficult to pump than a boy who is ready for his questioner , so I stared at him .
#Text=“ Lane ? ” I said , “ Lane ?
#Text=Do you mean the bo'sun ? ”
#Text=“ No , ” he said .
#Text=“ The Colonel .
#Text=You know ?
#Text=Eh ? ”
#Text=“ No. ” I said .
#Text=“ I do n't know . ”
#Text=“ Oh well , ” he answered .
#Text=“ It 's all one .
#Text=I suppose he 's not come over . ”
#Text=At this moment the mate came on deck with the carpenter , carrying a model ship which they had been making together in their spare time .
#Text=They nodded to the stranger , who gave them a curt “ How do ? ” as though they had parted from him only the night before .
#Text=The mate growled at me for wasting time on deck when I should be at work .
#Text=He sent me down to my usual job of getting the cabin ready for the breakfast of the gentlemen .
#Text=As I passed down the hatchway , I heard the carpenter say to the stranger , “ Well .
#Text=So what 's the news with Jack ? ”
#Text=It flashed into my mind that this man might be his friend , the “ Longshore Jack ” who was to keep an eye upon me as well as upon Mr. Jermyn .
#Text=It gave me a most horrid qualm to think this .
#Text=The man was so sly , so calm , so guarded , that the thought of him being on the look-out for me , to sell me to the Dutch captains , almost scared me out of my wits .
#Text=The mate brought him to the cabin as I was laying the table .
#Text=“ This is the cabin , ” he was saying , “ where the gentlemen messes .
#Text=That 's our stern-chaser , the gun there . ”
